text: [Music]
[Applause]
[Applause]
I am a paper
cutter I cut
stories so my process is very
straightforward I take a piece of paper
I visualize my
story sometime I sketch sometime I don't
and as my image is already inside the
paper I just have to remove what's not
from that
story so I didn't come to paper cutting
in a straight
line in fact I see it more as a
spiral I was not born with a blade in my
hand and I don't remember paper cutting
as a child as a teenager
I was sketching drawing and I wanted to
be an artist but I was also a
rebel and I left everything and went for
a long series of odd jobs so among them
I have been a
shepherdess a truck driver a factory
worker a cleaning lady I worked in
tourism for one year in Mexico
one year in Egypt I moved for two years
in
Taiwan and then I settled in New York
where I became a tour guide and I still
worked as a tour leader travel back and
forth in China Tibet and Central Asia so
of course it took time and I was nearly
40 and I decided it's time to start as
an
artist so I chose thank you
I chose paper cutting because paper is
cheap it's light and you can use it in a
lot of different ways and I chose the
language of
silhouette because graphically it's very
efficient and it's also just getting for
the essential of
things so the word silhouette comes from
a minister of Finance aen the silhouette
and he slashed so many
budgets that people said they couldn't
afford paintings anymore and they needed
to have their portrait Alf
silhouette
so I made series of images
cutting and I assembled them in
portfolios and people told told me like
these 36 views of the Empire State
Building they told me you're making
artist
books so artist books have a lot of
definition they come in a lot of
different shapes but to me they are
fascinating object to visually narrate a
story they can be with words or without
words and I have a passion for images
and for words
I love pun and their relation to the
unconscious I love Oddities of languages
and everywhere I lived I learned the
languages but never mastered them so I'm
always looking for the false cognates or
identical words in different languages
so as you can guess my mother tongue is
French and my daily language is English
so I did a series of work where it was
identical words in French and in English
so one of this work is the spelling
spider so the spelling spider is a
cousin of the spelling
be but is much more connected to the
web
and this spider spins a bilingual
alphabet so you can read architecture
active or or active architecture so this
spider goes through the whole alphabet
with identical adjectives and
substantives so if you don't know one of
these languages it's instant
learning and one ancient form of the
book is
Scrolls so scrolls are very convenient
because you can create a large image on
a very small
table so the unexpected consequences of
that is that you only see one part of
your image so it makes a very freestyle
architecture and they're making all
those kinds of windows so it's to look
beyond the surface it's to have a look
at different world and very often I've
been an outsider so I want to see how
how things works and what's
happening so each window is an image and
is a world that I often revisit and I
revisit this world thinking about the
image or cliche about what we want to do
and what are the words colloquialism
that we have with it the
Expressions it's all if so what if we
were living in balloon house
it would make a very uplifting
world and we would live a very low
footprint on the planet will be so
light so sometimes I view from the
inside like
egocentricity and the inner
circles sometimes it's a global view to
see our common roots and how we can use
them to catch
dreams and we can use them also as a
safety
net and my
Inspirations are very
eclectic I'm influenced by everything I
read everything I
see I have some stories that are
humorous like dead
beats other one
historical here it's candy City it's a
non sugarcoated history of sugar it goes
from slave trade to over consumption of
sugar with some Sweet Moments in
between and sometimes I have emotional
response to news such as the 2010
Haitian
earthquake other the time it's not even
my stories people tell me their life
their memories their aspiration and I
create a
mindscape i Channel their history for
they have a place to go back to look at
their life and its
possibilities I call them fraan
cities I cannot speak for all my images
so I'll just go through a few of my
words just with the title modic
electricity mad grow on Columbus
Circle reff
City a web of
time cowos City
daily
battles
Felicity floating
islands and at one point I had to do the
whole nine yards so it's actually a
paper cut that's nine yard
long so in life and in paper cutting
everything is connected one story is
leads to another I was also interested
in the physicality of this format
because you have to walk to see it and
parallel to my cutting is my running I
started with small image I started with
few miles larger image I started to run
marathon then I went to run 50k then 60k
then I ran 50 miles Ultra marathons and
I still feel I'm running it's just a
training to become a longdistance paper
cutter and running gives me a lot of
energy here it is a three weeks paper
cutting Marathon at the Museum of Arts
and Design in New York City the result
is Hells and Heavens it's two panels of
13 ft high they were installed in the
museum on two floors but in fact it's a
continuous image and I call it Hells and
Heavens because it's daily Hells and
daily Heavens there is no border in
between some people are born in hells
and against all Earth they make it to
Heavens other people make the opposite
trip that's the Border you have sweat
shops in Hells you have people renting
the wings in Heavens and then you have
all those individual stories where
sometimes you even have the same same
action and the result put you or in
Hells or in Heavens so the whole Hells
and Heavens is about Free Will and
determinism and in paper cutting you
have the drawing is the structure itself
so you can take it off the
wall here it's a artist book
installation called identity
project it's not
autobiographical identities they are
more our social identities and then you
can just walk behind them and try them
on so it's like the different layers of
what we are made of and what we present
to the world as an
identity and that's another artist Book
Project in fact in the picture you have
two of them it's one I'm wearing and one
that's an exhibition at the Center for
book art in New York City why do I call
it a book it's called fashion statement
and there is quotes about fashion so you
can read it and
also because the definition of artist
book is very
generous so artist books you take them
off the wall you take them for a walk
you can also install them as public art
here it's in Scotsdale Arizona and it's
called Flo
memories so it's regional
memories and they are just randomly
moved by the
wind I love public
art and I entered competitions for a
long time after eight years of rejection
I was thrilled to get my first
commission with the person for the art
in New York City it was for a merger
station for emergency work and
fireman I made an artist book that's in
stainless steel instead of paper I
called it working in the same direction
but I added Weather Vein on both sides
to show that they cover all
directions with public art I could also
make cut glass here it's faceted glass
in the Bronx and each time I make public
art I want something that's really
revent to the place it's installed so
for the subway New York I saw a
correspondence between riding the subway
and reading it is travel in time travel
on time and Bronx literature it's all
about Bronx writers and their
stories another Glass Project is in a
public library in San Jose California
so I made a vegetal point of view of the
growth of San Jose so I started in the
center with the aorn for the olon Indian
civilization then I have the fruits from
Europe for the ranchers and then the
fruit of the world for Silicon Valley
today and it's still growing so the
technique it's cut sandblasted etched
and printed glass into Architectural
Glass
and outside the library I wanted to make
a place to cultivate your mind I took
Library material who had fruit names in
their
title and I use them to make an orchard
walk with these fruits of knowledge I
also planted a biblo tree so it's a tree
and in its trunk you have the roots of
languages and it's all about
International writing systems and on the
branches you have Library material
growing you can also have function and
form with public art so in Aurora
Colorado it's a bench but you have a
bonus with this bench because if you sit
a long time in summer in shorts you will
walk away with temporarily branding of
the story element on your thighs
another functional work it's in the
south side of Chicago for a subway
station and it's called seeds of the
future are planted
today it's a story about transformation
and
connections so it acts as a screen to
protect the rail and the commuter and
not to have object falling on the rails
to be able to change fences and window
guards into flowers it's
fantastic and here I've been working for
the last three years with the South
Bronx developer to bring art to life to
lowincome buildings and affordable
housing so each building has its own
personality and sometimes it's about a
legacy of the neighborhood like in
morisa about the Jazz
history and for other project like in
Paris it's about the name of the street
it's called rud de prairi Prairie Street
so I brought back the rabbit the
dragonfly to stay in that street and in
2009 I was asked to make a poster to be
placed in the subway cars in New York
City for a year so that was a very
captive
audience and I wanted to give them an
escape I created all around town
it is a paper cutting and then after I
added color on the computer so I can
call it techn
crafted and along the way I'm kind of
making paper cuttings and adding other
techniques but the result it's always to
have stories so the stories they have a
lot of possibilities they have a lot of
scenarios I don't know the stories I
take image from our Global imagination
from cliche from things we are thinking
about from history and everybody is a
narrator because everybody has a story
to tell but more important is everybody
has to make a story to make sense of the
world and in all this universe it's like
imagination is the vehicle to be
transported with but the destination is
our minds and how we can reconnect with
the essential and with the magic and
it's all what story in is about
[Applause]
[Music]
